content.text: • Switch on. Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{S}\) on the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(l = 0.200 \text{m}\) from point \(\mathbf{A}\)
• Measure and record in Table 1.1 the current \(I\) in the circuit and the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the length \(l = 0.200 \text{m}\) of resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the length \(l = 0.200 \text{m}\) of resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\), using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) . Record \(R\) in the table
• Repeat the procedure using the distance \(l = 0.400 \text{m}\). Switch off
• Complete the column headings in the table
Calculate the difference between the two values for \(R\)
difference =   .........
• Switch on. Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{S}\) on the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(l = 0.500 \text{m}\) from point \(\mathbf{A}\)
• Measure and record the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V_{1}\)
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the length \(l = 0.500 \text{m}\) of resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\), using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\)
Use the short connecting lead provided to connect points \(\mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\)
Switch on. Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{S}\) on the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(l = 0.500 \text{m}\) from point \(\mathbf{A}\)
Measure and record the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V_{2}\)
Calculate the combined resistance \(R_{2}\) of resistance wires \(\mathbf{AB}\) and \(\mathbf{CD}\), using the equation \(R_{2} = \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\)
Use the results in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) to compare the resistance \(R_{1}\) of wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the resistance \(R_{2}\) of wires \(\mathbf{AB}\) and \(\mathbf{CD}\) connected together
Tick **one** box next to the description that most closely matches your results
There is no simple relationship between \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\)
Suggest two reasons why different students all carrying out this experiment carefully, with the same apparatus, may not obtain identical results
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of two resistance wires. The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1

Place the load \(\mathbf{P}\) on the metre rule at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Place the metre rule on the pivot at the \(45.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Place load \(\mathbf{Q}\) on the rule and adjust its position so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced
• Record, in Table 2.1, the distance a between the centre of load \(\mathbf{P}\) and the pivot
• Measure and record in the table the distance \(b\) from the centre of load \(\mathbf{Q}\) to the pivot

• Repeat the steps above, placing the load \(\mathbf{P}\) at the \(10.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(15.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(20.0 \text{cm}\) mark and \(25.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Keep the pivot at the \(45.0 \text{cm}\) mark each time. Record all the readings in the table
Plot a graph of \(b / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(a / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)
A student suggests that \(a\) is directly proportional to \(b\)
State whether your readings support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the graph line
• Use the balance provided to measure the mass \(m\), in grams, of the metre rule
m =
• Calculate the value of \(mX,\) where \(X = 0.05 \text{N} \text{cm} / \text{g}.\)
Use the value of \(a\) in the first row of Table 2.1 to calculate \(Pa\), where \(P = 1.00 \text{N}\). \(P\) is the weight of load \(\mathbf{P}\). Include the unit
Use the value of \(b\) in the first row of Table 2.1 to calculate \(Qb\), where \(Q = 0.80 \text{N}\). \(Q\) is the weight of load \(\mathbf{Q}\). Include the unit
A student states that \(Pa\) should be equal to \(Qb\)
Look carefully at Fig. 2.1 and your answers to (d) and suggest what the student has not realised
In this experiment, you will investigate the principle of moments
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Draw a line \(\mathbf{FE}\) to the left of the normal, and at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 3.1
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on the line \(\mathbf{FE}\), placing one pin close to \(\mathbf{E}\). Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\)

• Replace the block and observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Remove the block

Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{K}\) where this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\)
• Measure and record the angle \(\alpha\) between the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
\(\alpha =\)
• Measure and record the length \(x\) between points \(\mathbf{M}\) and \(\mathbf{K}\)
Repeat the steps in **(a)** but with the line \(\mathbf{FE}\) to the right of the normal

• Draw a line joining the new positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{Q}\) where this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\)
• Measure and record the angle \(\beta\) between the line joining the new positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
\(\beta =\)
• Measure and record the length \(y\) between points \(\mathbf{M}\) and \(\mathbf{Q}\)

A student suggests that the results for \(\alpha\) and \(x\) should be the same as the results for \(\beta\) and \(y\). State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
Suggest one precaution that you should take with this experiment to obtain reliable results
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this Question Paper between pages 8 and 9
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light passing through a transparent block
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance
Fig. 3.1
• Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper. Draw the outline of the block ABCD
• Remove the block and draw a normal **NL** at the centre of side **AB**. Label the point **E** where the normal crosses **AB**. Label the point **M** where the normal crosses **CD**
A student is investigating the effect of draughts (moving air) on the rate of cooling of hot water
The following apparatus is available:
electric fan with four speed settings
supply of hot water
thermometer
250 cm³ beaker
250 cm³ measuring cylinder
stopwatch
clamp, boss and stand
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of draughts on the rate of cooling of hot water. You are **not** required to carry out this investigation
You should:
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation
state the key variables that you would control
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation
